children.name: the first language you learn as a child
sb's native language
children.definition: yournative language/tonguethe first language that you learn tiếng mẹ đẻ
examples: French is his native tongue.

children.name: sb's mother tongue
children.definition: sb’s mother tongue the first language you learn as achild- use this especially to talk about sb who nowlives in a countrywhere adifferentlanguageis spoken: tiếng mẹ đẻ
examples: We run classes for students whose mother tongue is not English.

children.name: sb's first language
children.definition: sb’s first language the first language you learn as a child - use this when you arecomparingsomeone’s first language with other languages that they learn later: tiếng mẹ đẻ
examples: My first language is Dutch.
My daughter has several classmates whose first language is Bengali.

children.name: native speaker
children.definition: a native speaker of a language is someone who learned that language first as a child: người bản ngữ
examples: The book is aimed at learners of English rather than native speakers.
All our teachers are native speakers of English.
a native-speaker dictionary
native speaker of
There has been an assumption in the past that anyone who is a native speaker of English is equipped to teach English.
a native speaker of English

children.name: when sb can speak more than one language
sb's second language
children.definition: sb’s second language your second language is a language that you speak well and often use, but not the first language that you learned as a child: ngôn ngữ thứ hai
examples: Halima was born in Kenya. Her first language is Swahili, and her second language is English.

children.name: bilingual
children.definition: able to speak two languages very well: nói được hai thứ tiếng
examples: About 80 percent of the school’s students are bilingual.
She works as a bilingual secretary for an insurance company.

children.name: multilingual
children.definition: able to speak several languages very well: nói được đa ngôn ngữ
examples: Many people who work at the European Parliament are multilingual.

children.name: lingo
children.definition: a foreign language: tiếng nước ngoài

children.name: speak/know the lingo
examples: Travelling in Spain is much easier if you can speak the lingo.
I’d like to go to Greece, but I don’tspeak the lingo.

children.name: learn/pick up the lingo
examples: He picked up the local lingo straight away.

children.name: translate
children.definition: to change one language, especially in a piece of writing, into another: dịch, phiên dịch
examples: She has translated a number of his books.
translation[U] B1when you translate sth
Most computer programs that do automatic translation do not do a very good job.
simultaneous translationthe process of translating what someone is saying while they say it
Courtroom interpreters provided simultaneous translation.
machine translationspecialized the process of changing text from one language into another language using a computerdịch bằngmáytính

children.name: translate sth (from sth) into sth
examples: Translate the text from Italian into English.
Poetry doesn’t usually translate well.
Can you translate this into French?
The book has been translated into 27 languages.
The best translators usually translate from a foreign language into their native language.

children.name: translate as
examples: Dagda, an ancient Irish deity, literally translates as ‘the good god’.
Michael Meyer translated the play from the original Norwegian.

children.name: interpret
children.definition: to immediately translate what is being said to someone in a foreign language, so that it can be understood or replied to: phiên dịch, làm phiên dịch

children.name: No one in our tour group spoke Spanish so we had to ask the guide to interpret
examples: We’ll have to find someone who speaks Chinese to interpret the questions and answers for our guests.

children.name: interpret for
examples: I had to interpret for my boss on the last trip to Japan.
During lunch, Ben interpreted for Sasha, who didn’t speak a word of English.
We had to ask our guide to interpret for us.

children.name: put into U
children.definition: put sth into English/French/Japaneseetc British to translate a short piece of writing into a foreign language:

children.name: dịch cái gì đó thành tiếng Anh/tiếng Pháp/tiếng Nhật
examples: ▪ I’ve written a birthday message for Fabio. Could you put it into Italian for me?
Tôi đã gửi 1 tin nhắn chúc sinh nhật cho Fabio. Bạn có thể dịch nó sang tiếng Ý dùm tôi không?
▪ You lived in Berlin - help me put this into German.
Bạn sống ở Berlin - giúp tôi dịch cái này ra tiếng Đức với.

children.name: translator
children.definition: someone who translates from one language to another: Thông dịch viên, dịch giả
examples: ▪ She worked in Geneva as a translator.
Cô làm thông dịch viên tại Geneva.
▪ The publishers are looking for an American translator for his novels.
Các nhà xuất bản đang tìm kiếm một dịch giả người Mỹ cho các tiểu thuyết của ông ấy.

children.name: through a translatorusing a translator qua thông dịch viên
examples: ▪ Speaking through a translator, Li told of his early life.
Thông qua một phiên dịch, Li kể về cuộc sống hồi nhỏ của mình.

children.name: interpreter
children.definition: someone who immediately translates spoken language, for example when politicians from different countries are speaking to each other: Phiên dịch viên
examples: ▪ If I’m going to make the speech, I’ll need an interpreter.
▪ Both Presidents were accompanied by their interpreters.

children.name: through an interpreterusing an interpreter qua phiên dịch viên
examples: The only way we could figure out what they were saying was through an interpreter.

children.name: translation
children.definition: a piece of language, especially a piece of writing, that has been changed from one language into another: bản dịch
examples: translation of
a new translation of the Bible
translation from
a literal translation from Arabic
direct translation
be lost in (the) translationwhen the real meaning of something cannot be translated in a completely satisfactory way
Much of the humour of the book was unfortunately lost in translation.
lose sth in (the) translation
His arguments are still powerful, but I think they lose some impact in translation.
The English version is boring - perhaps it haslostsomethingintranslation

children.name: do/make a translation of sth
examples: She had done a translation of the poem.
It goes without saying’ is a direct translation of a French phrase.

children.name: a rough/free translation
children.definition: one that is not very exact
examples: It’s a rough translation but I think the meaning is clear.

children.name: an accurate/exact translation
examples: The most accurate translation of the word would be ‘master’.

children.name: a literal translation
children.definition: one in which each word is translated exactly
examples: First make a literal translation and then try and put it into idiomatic English.

children.name: an
examples: English/French etc translationHe wrote the first English translation of Homer’s 'Iliad'.

children.name: Much of the book’s humour has been lost in translation
children.definition: is no longer effective when translated

children.name: version
children.definition: English/Japanese/French etcversion a translation of a book, poem etc in that language: phiên bản dịch
examples: ▪ Most people would agree that the Italian version sounds better.

children.name: version of
examples: ▪ I had trouble understanding the French, so I got the English version of the book from the library and read it.

children.name: in translation
children.definition: if you read something in translation, you read it after it has been translated from another language: qua bản dịch
examples: ▪ I don’t really like reading poetry in translation.
▪ All of Brecht’s plays are available in translation.

children.name: to speak a little of a foreign language
get by
children.definition: to speak enough of a language to be able to buy things, ask for help etc:
examples: ▪ He went to Tokyo and within a few weeks knew enough Japanese to get by.

children.name: get by in
examples: ▪ I’ve just bought a book called ‘Get By In Portuguese’.

children.name: know a few words
children.definition: to be able to speak a few words of a language:
examples: ▪ ‘Do you speak Korean?’ ‘I only know a few words.’
know a few words of
▪ I used to know a few words of German but I’ve forgotten them all.

children.name: have a smattering of
children.definition: to be able to speak a small but useful amount of a language:
examples: ▪ Martin is fluent in French, and also has a smattering of Swedish.

children.name: broken
examples: broken English/French etcEnglish, French etc that is spoken slowly and badly by someone who only knows a little of the language:
The two students, one Chinese, the other Greek, communicated in broken English.

children.name: speak
examples: ▪ Nadia speaks six languages.
speakFrench/Japanese/Russian etc
▪ Is there anyone here who can speak Arabic?
speakverbspoke,spokenLANGUAGE nói(một ngôn ngữ)
[ T ] to (be able to) talk in a language
_He speaks fluent French.
_How many foreign languages do you speak?
_I couldn't speaka word of(= I did not know any) Spanish when I got there.
_I couldn't work out what language they were speaking.

children.name: know
children.definition: to be able to speak, read, and understand some of a particular foreign language:
examples: ▪ I know enough Italian to travel around there.
Do you know any Polish?
knowverbknew,knownBE FAMILIAR WITH
[ T not continuous ]If you know a language, you can speak and understand it
_Do you know any French?

children.name: speaker
children.definition: someone who can speak a particular language: speaker of English/Russian/Arabic etc
examples: ▪ Speakers of Cantonese often cannot understand speakers of Mandarin.
English/Spanish/Urdu etc speaker
▪ The hotel has two English speakers on its staff.
native speaker
learnt a particular language as their first language as a child
▪ All our English teachers are native speakers.
speakernoun[ C ]LANGUAGEngười nói(một ngôn ngữ)
someone who speaks a particular language
_a French speaker
_afluentRussian speaker
_non-English speakers

children.name: fluent
children.definition: very good at speaking a foreign language, so that you can speak it quickly without stopping and you understand it very well:
examples: fluently[adv] B2
I'd like to speak English fluently.
Douglas speaks Hindi fluently.
fluency[U] B2
One of the requirements of the job is fluencyintwo or more African languages.

children.name: fluent in English/German/Thai etc
examples: Applicants should be fluent in Cantonese.
She's fluentinFrench.

children.name: fluent French/Arabic/Japanese etc
examples: Ann speaks fluent Italian.
He's a fluent Russian speaker.

children.name: bilingual
children.definition: (of a thing) using or involving two languages
examples: a bilingual dictionary

children.name: monolingual
children.definition: speaking or using only one language: đơn ngữ
examples: This is a monolingual dictionary.

children.name: multilingual
children.definition: (of a thing) written or spoken in more than two different languages: đa ngữ
examples: a multilingual on-line dictionary

children.name: target language
children.definition: the language that you are learning or that you are translating intongôn ngữ mục tiêu

children.name: linguist
children.definition: sb who studies foreign languages or can speak themvery well, or sb who teaches or studies linguistics: nhà ngôn ngữ học
